captions.text:
Oh, thank goodness. My dietician was getting 
concerned I hadn&#39;t been eating enough shit

lately. I mean, I gotta nominate the five worst 
games of the year in about six months&#39; time, and

I&#39;ve hardly been hating anything so far. Between 
The Alters and a string of basically okay stuff,

I&#39;ve hardly had enough bile in me lately to digest 
my fucking 8:00 AM White Russian. Thank you,

Build a Rocket Boy. I didn&#39;t realize that was the 
developer&#39;s name at first; when the ident came up,

I thought I was being issued an instruction, 
but I digress. Thank you for brewing up

MindsEye in the witch&#39;s cauldron of AAA money and 
behind-the-scenes drama, a game with such a vast,

smelly, monumental arse that when it bends 
over at the equator, there&#39;s an eclipse at

the tropics. And I&#39;m aware I&#39;m not making 
any earth-shattering revelations here;

the contours and geography of this particular 
arse have been well mapped out for weeks,

but like I was gonna pass up the opportunity to 
kick the teeth out of this dead horse. Shittiness

this rich and pungent deserves to be savored. I 
wanna have a nice, long slow dance with MindsEye,

get its legs all tangled up in the strips of 
toilet paper that litter the ballroom, then twirl

it out onto the balcony under the moonlight, 
meet its gaze, and shove it over the rail.

Mind Shite tells us the story of Jacob Diaz—whoa, 
I&#39;m sending that straight off to the Museum of

Arse-Achingly Generic Protagonist Names; that&#39;s 
right up there with &quot;Alex Mason&quot; but with a

spicy tang of multiculturalism—a former Special 
Ops soldier who moves to that one glittering,

high-tech future city in the desert tech bros 
and Saudi princes are always threatening to

impose upon the world, where his childhood friend 
manages to get him a job as a senior security

officer for the billionaire tech bro company 
behind everything. A job he was apparently

able to get him without his physical presence 
or indeed him needing to be contacted at all,

presumably using the same method by which that 
one dude got a bunch of mail order degrees

for his cat. But wait, there&#39;s an explanation 
for this: the billionaire tech bro cuntbucket

wanted Jacob specifically because the military 
plugged a super secret tech implant in his neck

and something happened in the Middle East that 
infected him with an alien virus or something

that either makes robots want to kill him 
or gives him the power to control them.

I dunno, the plot&#39;s kinda inconsistent with that 
one. Anyway, Jacob Protagonist has no memory of

what happened in the desert, and now his sole 
driving motivation is to get to the bottom of

the strange incident that changed his life 
forever. Or do a really good job protecting

the billionaire tech bro wanksandwich who 
employs him now. Or get revenge on the

military. Or get his leg over this one hacker 
girl he rescues at one point. Another thing the

plot&#39;s a bit inconsistent on. Mind Your Backs 
is a slightly GTA-adjacent open-world game.

But I don&#39;t think anybody told IT that. 
There&#39;s undeniably an open world in it,

which we can theoretically freely explore in the 
provided vehicles, but the moment we try to do so,

the game has a massive panic attack like 
we&#39;re wandering perilously close to the

chest freezer containing the corpse of the 
person who actually owns this house. You&#39;re

immediately locked into a story mission 
and told to drive to such and such a place,

and if you do anything other than fucking floor 
it and arrive with smoking tires and a neighbor&#39;s

picket fence wrapped around your rear spoiler, an 
NPC rings you up and yells at you. &quot;WHY THE FUCK

AREN&#39;T YOU AT THE MISSION DESTINATION YET?! WHO 
DO YOU THINK YOU ARE, A PERSON WITH FREE WILL?!&quot;

Finish the mission and you&#39;re immediately 
inescapably locked into the next story

mission and obliged to drive all the 
way back across the city with shouty,

naggy NPC tagging out for the next story-relevant 
shouty, naggy NPC to start nagging you to get

your arse in gear. And so on until the game 
ends, about 60% of which, in retrospect, was

spent driving across mostly empty roads getting 
nagged. Man, between this and Mario Kart World,

what is it with games being embarrassed of their 
open worlds lately? Is it &#39;cause they&#39;re so common

now it&#39;s considered unclassy to show them off, 
like wearing a full military dress uniform to your

mate&#39;s barbecue? Well, that analogy only works for 
MindsEye if your dress uniform consists of a KFC

bucket and three handfuls of shit because you&#39;re 
in the shit army for twats. And Mine&#39;s a Pint is

perhaps justifiably embarrassed of its open world 
because there&#39;s fuck all in it. A bit of city,

a lot of desert, and very little in the way 
of shit to do. As for the percentage of the

game that isn&#39;t spent driving around at slightly 
less than what the game considers optimal speed,

it&#39;s mostly token rounds of pedestrian 
cover-based shooting against very inept enemies.

The plot makes a fuss out of this drone that 
Jacob has that&#39;s supposed to be his superpower,

but its only real function is to delete a 
single target from the battlefield every

time the cooldown is up. Oh, thank goodness, 
now I can get back to driving around the city

faster. There&#39;s also a couple of tailing 
missions and precisely one instance of a

safecracking minigame, both of which made me 
go, &quot;Yeah, I suppose you&#39;ve made your point,

MindsEye. Things could always be worse; back 
to the terrible shooting, please.&quot; I wondered

if this was a Ride to Hell situation—meaning 
something intended to be open world that had

to scale back to a linear experience &#39;cause they 
couldn&#39;t be arsed to do the extra legwork, not

just that the game&#39;s a big pile of bum—but then 
I was picking through the menus and found a great

big list of optional race challenges laid out in 
a neat list. Where the fuck were these? Why didn&#39;t

you scatter them across the map to be discovered 
organically; it would&#39;ve taken five seconds! This

is one of those games that&#39;s always going to be 
fascinating to autopsy, preferably very suddenly

and violently with a two-foot scalpel because 
there&#39;s so much about it I just can&#39;t fathom.

The plot is so elaborately told with full-on 
mocapped cutscenes and characters and yet makes

so little sense. Why does there just happen to 
be a secret alien temple underneath the city,

and why do we go there to confront the big 
villain, fail, backtrack all the way out

of the temple, do another, unrelated mission, 
then go back to the secret alien temple again

&#39;cause we just remembered, &quot;Oh, shit, the big 
villain was there; should probably confront

them properly&quot;? The plot only stops vacillating 
randomly between characters and tones and themes

when it runs out of gas and ends about as abruptly 
and satisfyingly as a shotgun blast to the lower

leg. And I still have so many questions. This 
billionaire tech bro clitbrisket thinly disguised

Elon Musk stand-in character, for example. Am I 
supposed to think he&#39;s a spoiled, superficial,

manipulative cunt or a misunderstood, visionary 
genius? &#39;Cause that&#39;s another thing the plot

goes back and forth on until by the end, most 
of what we seem to be doing is defending the

guy&#39;s visionary tech projects from evil 
government and military people who want

to repress him with their evil regulations. Oh 
god, you don&#39;t actually like Elon Musk, do you,

developers? I bet you do. I bet you&#39;re one of 
those people who defends him at parties. Until we

can politely shake you off and get back to talking 
with the dude wearing three handfuls of shit.
